Fields.DialogueText: Is that a Morgana on the horizon? Report! I need a report!
You know, that does look like a Morgana out there.
I know it looks like a Morgana, but I need to know whether it really is. And what are you doing, just standing there? Don't you have a job to be doing?
*ALARM*
Apparently, it is a Morgana. Crew, get to your sta...
... Did they just turn off the klaxon?
You must be kidding me.
Kapitan, my apologies, there's some confusion over the sighting north of us.
I hadn't noticed. Tell the officers to get their act together!
*ALARM*

Fields.MenuText: I wonder how long the alarms will remain on this time...
Officer Petrov, tell the officers that a lengthy, unpleasant conversation is in their future.
We'll see if those officers are still alive by the time the battle starts.

Fields.DialogueText: I think this might be the real thing.
I'm... sure they'll be looking forward to it, Kapitan.
You're looking awfully... murderous, Kapitan.
Moskva! Is that a Morgana, or isn't it?
Can you not smell her from here? That is a Morgana.
Well, that information would have been helpful a few minutes ago. Are you ready to fight?
I'm always ready to fight.
... All right, then.
@BATTLE
Moskva, I must say, the crew aboard this ship are some of the most unruly I've ever seen in my life.
Why are you telling me this, Kapitan?

Fields.MenuText: Uh... I just felt the need to vent.
This is your ship, Moskva. Your name is on the side.
You know, I realize we haven't known one another long, but you do seem like one of the more snobbish individuals I've ever met.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm sure.
My name might be on the side, but you are in command.
If you equate snobbery with discipline and pride, then I'll take your words as a compliment.
The crew I had aboard this ship prior to the war was one of the most disciplined in all of Russia. I fought to keep them following my ship's inclusion into the Protection Force...
...but they were replaced by this unbridled excuse for a crew. If they aren't behaving, well then, that's on you.
That's... not entirely incorrect. But I must admit, trying to handle this crew while fending off the Morganas and satisfying the wants of Command has been... difficult.
Do you want my help?
Hmm?
Do you want my help disciplining the crew? I've held out until now, not wanting to interfere. But if you think my help could be of use...
Yes, please. If you think you can do anything...
*ALARM*
Let me assure you, Kapitan. I don't think. I know.
@BATTLE
Looks like the intelligence was good. How long until we intercept the enemy?
I wouldn't wander off.
Heh.
@BATTLE
Captain, what do you think you're doing?
Excuse me?
Why are we heading south?
Those are our orders from Command.
But those Morganas are fleeing north, directly toward Spain. We need to pursue them!
There are other ships with the Protection Force already in position, off Spain. We have our orders to move south.
That's not good enough! My fam...
You'll want to return to your duties, Officer.
You know what, Belle? You can go to...
*SPLASH*

Fields.MenuText: You... you just threw that officer overboard.
I must admit, you took care of that problem quickly.
You're surprisingly strong for how tiny you are.

Fields.DialogueText: You are correct.
If only all problems were so quickly remedied.
What is the English saying? Looks can be deceiving?
I'll do the same to any who rebelliously question your orders. The crew must understand that your word is final.
Shouldn't we rescue Officer Cardona? He appears to be struggling.
I suppose, although I'm not sure I understand the point of keeping a naval officer who is such a poor swimmer.
Wake up, Kapitan.
Whuh...?
It's time to run drills. I've already laid out your clothes for you. Get dressed, and meet me outside.

Fields.MenuText: I appreciate... whatever it is, you're doing. But please, Moskva. Let me sleep.
Remember how you said my word is final? This is my final word.
I would rather die than leave this bed.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm afraid that isn't a possibility.
While I respect your authority, I ask that you reconsider.
That seems a bit dramatic, don't you think, Kapitan?
The entire crew is running - it will improve their camaraderie, I assure you. And seeing you there, running with them? It will strengthen their respect for you at the same time.
The entire crew is up?
Well, if they aren't, they will be soon.
Attention, all crew and officers! Everyone up and on deck!
Was that... Officer Cardona?
It was. He's been very mindful of my orders, since...
... Since you tossed him off the boat?
Of course.
*ALARM*
You had him sound the alarm, too?
No...
@BATTLE
The enemy's almost in range, Kapitan. Be at your best.
Thank you for that.
@BATTLE
That last battle went better than we could have anticipated, Captain. I'd call it a success, even.
You and the rest of the crew did seem more capable today. Excellent work.
Much as I hate to say it, I think we owe Moskva's drills a debt of gratitude. We're running like a well-oiled machine, now.

Fields.MenuText: I think you're absolutely correct.
Don't get too effusive with your praise... although, I'd say you're probably right.
Don't let her hear that. I think she's plenty confident, as is.

Fields.DialogueText: Those drills have been hell, but it's been worth it in battle.
I don't think a little praise for Moskva would be uncalled for.
Is there a bit of a rivalry between you two?
I do worry about her, though.
You worry... about Moskva?
I've heard about some of the other Belles who've popped up - seen a couple of them with my own eyes.
Compared to the rest of them, Moskva just seems a little... joyless.
I can't disagree with you there...
No...
If you say so, Captain.
The enemy's almost in range, Kapitan.
Did that targeting issue with the AA guns get resolved?
Of course it did.
Did you have to throw anyone overboard?
No. But the day's still young.
@BATTLE
That was a good fight, Moskva. You really are very graceful in battle.
Grace is an oft overlooked quality in fighters, Kapitan. Without it, many open themselves up to needless injury.
While an abundance of it puts our enemies to flight.
That might have more to do with intimidation than it does grace, Kapitan.
You know, Moskva...?
Hmm?
I know this is a bit of a non sequitur, but a conversation with one of the crew set me to thinking...

Fields.MenuText: Do you ever do anything... for fun?
I need you to relax.
Has anyone ever told you you might be a little too... intimidating?

Fields.DialogueText: For fun?
Why?
You're asking a destroyer to be less intimidating?
I protect you and the crew. I defeat Morganas. What... else would you have me do? Is there something I lack?
No, not exactly. But as captain, it's my responsibility to ensure that all of my crew is well. And I just want to make sure... that you're happy.
We are at war. Happiness is not a concern of mine. Now, please, excuse me.
Huh.
My, Moskva, your living quarters certainly are... sparse.
I prefer to live simply. Quietly. Owning many things only serves to complicate matters.
I suppose that's true... hmm? Well, well, what's this picture?
Ah, that? That's my older sister, Leningrad, and I, when we were younger.
You're dancing ballet...

Fields.MenuText: A dancer and a fighter. Those two seem to be at odds with one another, don't they?

Fields.DialogueText: Grace isn't innate, Kapitan. It's taught.
Your sister, she doesn't look too... comfortable.
Much comes easily to my sister. Dancing did not. Thus, it wasn't her favorite activity.

Fields.MenuText: You look completely at ease, though. Do you still dance?

Fields.DialogueText: Not recently. Speaking of which... I do believe we have visitors heading this way, Kapitan.
Of course we do.
@BATTLE
You look completely at ease, though. Do you still dance?

Fields.MenuText: I bet you're a natural.

Fields.DialogueText: Kapitan, would it be too much to ask that you tell me what's going on? You told me to follow you, and you've led me down into the depths of the ship...
I have a surprise for you.
Down here? I can't imagine what... wait. What's all this? What are these mirrors doing in this room?
This room has been sitting empty for some time now. We have no plans to use it for anything else, and I thought it might make you a nice practice room.
A practice room? For what?
Ballet, of course!

Fields.MenuText: Do you like it?
It's important that my crew have downtime between battles. If dancing is how you unwind, then I want you dancing.
Of course, it would make an excellent practice room for staring contests, as well.

Fields.DialogueText: It is very considerate of you.
Your concern for your crew is admirable.
I'm sure that's true, Kapitan.
My decision to give up dancing - it was a decision, not some mere effect of the war.
The crew needs my full attention and help. I can't give them that attention if my focus is split between them and ballet.
... All right, then.
@BATTLE
The food served aboard this ship certainly is... unique.
It does have a Soviet flair to it, doesn't it?
... ballet company told me I could audition again following my service in the war, but I'm just not sure whether...
Hold my food, would you, Officer Cardona?
Yes, Captain!
Officer Petrov! What was that you were just saying?
Kapitan! Oh, uh... ahem. Prior to the war, I had been accepted... to a rather prestigious ballet company. Then, I received my orders to serve aboard this ship...
The company told me I could audition again following my service, but I know I've fell behind in my practices since being here.
I'm not sure, following the war, whether I'll be capable of what I once was. It's just the truth of the matter.

Fields.MenuText: What if I told you things might not be quite as hopeless as you assume they are?
It always amazes me how often the crew is able to meet one another's needs.
(smirks)

Fields.DialogueText: What makes you say that?
You think another member of the crew could help me?
That's an impish smile you have on your face.
*ALARM*
Petrov, find me after this battle. Understand?
Yes... Kapitan.
@BATTLE
What was it you wanted to discuss, Kapitan?
Moskva! There you are - I've been looking everywhere for you.
Da? What is it, Kapitan?
This is Officer Petrov. Have you met?
Your first name is Evgeny, correct?
Yes, Comrade Moskva.
Kapitan, why is your expression that of a cat who's made off with a canary?

Fields.MenuText: I have good news for you, Moskva.
You're interested in helping the crew, aren't you?
What an apt description, Moskva.

Fields.DialogueText: Do you, now?
Da - why? Is Officer Petrov in need of help?
You still haven't given me an explanation for such an expression.
Tell her, Officer Petrov.
Well... I was accepted to a ballet company prior to the war, but will have to audition again following the war. And I'm fearful my ability is already in decline.
Officer Petrov is in need of help, Moskva. Can you show me someone on board this ship who would be a greater asset to him in his time of need than you?
Moskva? Why are you walking away? Moskva?
*ALARM*
Perhaps she sensed the incoming Morganas?
Doubtful.
@BATTLE
Moskva? Moskva, slow down!
We need to speak.
I am quite unhappy with you, Kapitan. It isn't right that you drag Officer Petrov into this apparently uncontainable need for you to see me happy.
Forcing your officers to lie for you is abominable.
Lie? Officer Petrov didn't lie.
You expect me to believe that you just happened to find another ballet dancer aboard this ship? A ballet dancer in need of my help?
I mean, it isn't so unbelievable, is it?
You're a dancer? A real dancer?
Yes!
Show me your Fouetté turns.
Here? In these trousers?
Yes. If you're a real dancer, it shouldn't be a problem.
All right, all right. I'll give it my best go.

Fields.MenuText: Goodness, look at him! That's pretty impressive, Moskva.
Those trousers are more flexible than I would have expected. What technology enables this?
This is one of the funniest things I've seen since the war started.

Fields.DialogueText: Hmm, he does seem to have a strong sense of balance.
I must agree with you on that count.
Don't tease him, Kapitan.
You may stop, Officer Petrov. You do have some skill. Find me after this next battle, and we will begin your training.
Thank you, Comrade Moskva.
@BATTLE
Tell me, Officer Petrov - which ballet company are you auditioning for?
Kirov...
In Leningrad? Promise me you won't tell my sister. It will go straight to her head.
Your sister? What...?
You're fine, Officer Petrov. Just nod and do whatever she tells you to do.
Yes, Kapitan.
As I'm sure you're aware, Officer Petrov, for your audition, you will need to show yourself capable of competent solo and partner work.

Fields.MenuText: You certainly sound as if you know what you're talking about, Moskva.
I'm sure Officer Petrov is up to the task.
It's strange how expressionless your face remains, even when you're talking about something you find interesting.

Fields.DialogueText: I only speak if I have knowledge of the subject at hand.
We'll see.
We'll see to your solo work first. Officer Petrov, are you ready?
Yes, of course...
*ALARM*
Yes, that seems about right.
@BATTLE
Officer Petrov! How has your first practice... good grief, you're covered in sweat.
*wheeze*
Today, we discovered that Officer Petrov's stamina could use some improvement.
*wheeze*
Our time at sea has diminished his lung capacity that much? Should we take him to sick bay? He looks as if he's about to pass out.
Don't mind him. He'll recover. And I've given him a lengthy list of exercises to do between now and our next practice. You will see to them, won't you, Officer Petrov?
Yes, *wheeze* Comrade...
I'm glad to hear it.

Fields.MenuText: I'm sure those exercises will be just the ticket!
She is... quite the taskmaster.
Oy.

Fields.DialogueText: *wheeze* I think so!
*wheeze* I know!
*wheeze*
Actually, *wheeze* she reminds me just of my instructors back home. For the first time, *wheeze* I'm thinking this might work!
Unbelievable.
*ALARM*
Come now, Petrov. Let's go.
@BATTLE
More practice, Moskva?
There's always more practice to be had, Kapitan.
Isn't that the same... move you had Officer Petrov do before? The... turns?
Fouetté turns? Yes, they are. While his balance was always commendable, his speed of rotation needed improvement.
Bear in mind, I don't know much about ballet, but... I think those turns look more polished.
Why do you say that?

Fields.MenuText: He looks more confident?
He looks more steady?
He's no longer grimacing?

Fields.DialogueText: He does, doesn't he?
Yes, his steadiness has improved.
I suppose you're right, on that count.
Officer Petrov has shown remarkable improvement. I've been pleased to find his muscle memory intact. His previous instructors were commendable, indeed.
And yet, he wouldn't be showing improvement, now, if it wasn't for you. Surely that feels good.
Moskva?
Officer Petrov! You may stop. Kapitan, I believe we have a few Morganas headed our direction.
@BATTLE
You know, Moskva, this is the strongest my dancing ability has been in some time. It feels amazing.
Which is why we're switching to partner work, effective immediately.
Naturally.
We must keep you well-rounded. Focusing solely on solo work would not be for your benefit.

Fields.MenuText: I'm sure Officer Petrov will benefit from having a partner such as yourself, Moskva.
I must say, I'm interested to finally see your own ability, Moskva.
Do Belles have muscle memory?

Fields.DialogueText: A partner? Me?
Why on earth would you say that?
Do we... what?
No, no, Kapitan. You are under the wrong impression. I will not be partnering with Officer Petrov.
What?
How...?
But you're...
But nothing. Surely we can find another dancer onboard this ship.
*ALARM*
And we'll find said dancer following this battle.
@BATTLE
Moskva, we've asked nearly every crew member and officer on board this ship. When are you going to accept that...
Shush. There's Officer Petrov. He looks as if he has news.
Kapitan, Moskva! See that officer, over there? I swear I just heard her tell her friends she danced back home.
Officer... Collins?

Fields.MenuText: She... might not be the right choice, Officer Petrov.
She is not the most disciplined officer aboard this ship.
Moskva, why are veins popping out of your forehead?

Fields.DialogueText: That would be an understatement.
Convincing her to run drills was a nightmare.
Quiet, you.
I do not think Officer Collins to have the technique necessary to be of help to you, Evgeny.
What other choice do we have?
Stop staring at me, both of you. Fine, ask her if she cares to help. If so, we'll see what she can do. After this next battle.
@BATTLE
Officer Collins, Petrov, do you understand the steps as I outlined them for you?
Yes, Comrade Moskva.
Shall I start the music?
Yes, please, Kapitan.
(Music plays. Dun... dun... dun...)
Stop.
What?!
Officer Collins, you may leave.
We only performed two steps.
Any further steps would have been a detriment to the work we've done, so far, Evgeny. You would have had to compensate for her weaknesses.
She didn't seem too pleased.
I wonder why.
Moskva, if not Officer Collins, who do you expect Officer Petrov to dance with?
Stop staring at me! Fine, yes, I'll dance with you. But only as long as you're in need of such help. And only provided the Kapitan refrains from smirking.
*ALARM*
I will... do my best.
@BATTLE
Yes, Comrade Moskva.
(Music plays. Dun... dun... dunnnnn...)
Wow, Officer Petrov, Moskva - that was excellent! I mean, I only caught the end and I'm hardly qualified as a judge, but I thought it was phenomenal.

Fields.MenuText: Moskva? What...? Officer Petrov, what happened?
That was hardly respectful.
Clearly, the dancing is helping her stern demeanor.

Fields.DialogueText: Everything's all right... more or less.
Please don't hold it against her, Kapitan.
It was her first time dancing in quite a while.
One section kept giving her trouble. Not even a section, really. Just a few, admittedly complicated steps. But missing those few steps frustrated her.
That's a bit of an understatement.
*ALARM*
Well, she's a better fighter while she's angry. Come on, Officer Petrov. Let's watch the Morganas flee from her wrath.
@BATTLE
Have you finished practicing already, Officer Petrov? I've been busy seeing to the ship since the battle ended - how did everything go?
It was a good practice, although...
What?
Those steps are still giving Moskva trouble. She ended our practice early so she could drill the steps herself.
You're kidding.
I'm afraid not. She feels that any error on her part could negatively impact my training, and refuses to be a burden.
That's... hardly surprising, knowing what I do of her.
I'm a little worried about her, and was wondering if you might...
Keep an eye on her? Yeah, I'll see what I can do. Thank you, Officer Petrov.
Of course, Kapitan.
@BATTLE
Moskva? You're still practicing? Didn't you wrap up with Officer Petrov quite a while ago?
Those steps are still giving me problems. I have to master them before my inability affects Evgeny.
I assure you, a few missed steps will have no detrimental effect on him. Your instruction is too good for that.
I will not risk it.
Moskva will you... just, stand still for a second, would you?
What? Why?
Look at yourself. You're exhausted.
I'm fine.

Fields.MenuText: I'm not sure I believe that, Moskva.
I have a responsibility to look out for you. I'm not liking what I'm seeing.
I can see your legs shaking from here.

Fields.DialogueText: Believe what you want. It won't affect what I do.
Does that really matter?
A little fatigue never hurt anyone.
I push my personal boundaries, just like I pushed those of the crew when we needed them to act as a team. It's how we better ourselves.
As long as you don't push yourself overboard like you did with Officer Cardona.
Moskva?
I won't. Now, let's go. Morganas are headed this way.
@BATTLE
They're almost in range. Are we... Moskva?
Da?
If I didn't know better, I'd say that you were fidgeting.
I do not... fidget. I'm just eager to begin.
Then I think you're in luck.
@BATTLE
Moskva! Moskva!
... What is it, Kapitan?
What was that? I've never seen you so... awkward in battle.
We won, didn't we?

Fields.MenuText: We did, but that doesn't lessen the concern I feel for you.
We won, but my crew was not operating at the level I've come to expect.
For a Belle who prides herself on her grace, I didn't see much of it, out there today.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't be so sentimental, Kapitan.
By crew, you just mean me, don't you?
I'm not allowed to have one off day?
Comrade Moskva, I've been thinking...
What, Evgeny?
I think we should halt my practices for a little while.
What?
Officer Petrov and I discussed it, and we both think it would be for the best. Just for a few days, so you can have some time to rest.
She does that a lot, have you noticed?
There are worse ways of dealing with conflict, I suppose.
Moskva? What are you doing? I told you you needed to rest!
I wasn't happy with you, Kapitan, when you told me I needed to take a break. But in spite of that, I took some time to really consider your words.
I find that difficult to believe, considering we're having this conversation while you're still dancing.
I would have never endangered the crew - I know my own boundaries, what I'm capable of. But I don't want to cause you needless worry, either.
So, I've implemented regular times of rest into my schedule. I've felt some effect since doing so - I do feel better rested than I did a few days ago.
That isn't quite what Officer Petrov and I had in mind.
You gave me advice. I heard said advice. I made use of said advice in the best way I knew how.
I would think that doing so would show the respect I have for you - there are few people on this earth whose advice I would take so readily.
Now, it's your turn to trust me.

Fields.MenuText: How am I supposed to do that?
Is that a fact?
You're eerily efficient at talking others into corners, you know that?

Fields.DialogueText: For starters, listen to what I have to say.
Yes.
I learned that from my older sister.
I gave a little - I am now resting. I'd ask that you do the same.
You want me to rest?
No, I want you to give a little. Recognize that, with regular periods of rest, my practicing likely won't put the ship in harm's way.
... All right. But I'm going to hold you to those periods of rest.
Of course, Kapitan. Now, we'd better be going. Morganas are headed for us.
@BATTLE
I don't know that I've ever seen anyone practice as dutifully as Moskva does.
She is determined, isn't she? She works on those steps, over and over and over, never stopping...
She just stopped.

Fields.MenuText: She did? Is she hurt?
I find that difficult to believe.
I'm sure she did so just to spite me.

Fields.DialogueText: It doesn't look like it.
Look for yourself.
I don't think she could have heard you from here, Kapitan.
She's just... standing there. What's going...?
I did it!
Is she smiling?
Good Lord, she is smiling.
Did you see that? Did you two see that? I did it! Watch, watch - I'll do it again!
Well, look at that! Those are the steps. I know some dancers who've worked on those steps for years, to no avail. It's no small feat, Kapitan.
Excellent work, Moskva!
There are Morganas headed this way. Come on, you two - I'm feeling especially energized.
@BATTLE
Officer Petrov? That's a melancholic look on your face.
Is everything all right? You didn't pull another muscle, did you?
I received a letter from Command. I had hoped to return home in the next few months, but... well, it looks as if I won't be leaving you two any time soon.
Our apologies, Petrov. That's a tough blow.
Oh, everything will be fine.
You're... suspiciously chipper.
I am not. Listen, Evgeny, I know this is disappointing, but I promise you - no matter when you finally do return home, I will have you ready to audition again.
And until that day arrives, well, you'll just get to spend more time under my tutelage.
Such a notion would scare off lesser men. But she's right, Petrov. As long as you're aboard this ship, you'll have a place to practice.
Thank you, both. That... means a lot.
Now... shall we fight the Morganas headed in from the northeast?
@BATTLE
You know, Moskva, you're a little enigmatic.
Whatever would make you say that, Kapitan?
When I first met you, well... you're a little prickly, you know?
Figuratively speaking, I'm sure.
Yes, of course. But all this time we've spent working with Officer Petrov, I've seen... there is a caring side to you. It presents itself in odd ways, but I know it's there.
This conversation is getting too sentimental for my tastes.
I know, I know. All of this, just to say - I'm glad you chose me as your captain. And I'm looking forward to spending many days with you, in the future.
I... would say something similar. You are a good kapitan, and I'm honored to serve you.
Thank you, Moskva.
*ALARM*
We best be on our way.

Fields.MenuText: She is a handful, but I'm happy she's on my side.
Is it possible that I could have... feelings, for someone so prickly?

Fields.DialogueText: Don't keep us waiting, Kapitan!
Are you talking to yourself, Kapitan?
